importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the White House officially began demolishing part of the East Wing to start construction of the new ballroom, marking a significant escalation in construction activity despite legal and regulatory uncertainties.
The date when President Trump first announced the project, claiming the ballroom would not interfere with the existing White House structure and promising it would be privately funded.
The date when site preparation work, including clearing of trees on the south grounds, began, indicating the start of early-phase construction activities.
The projected completion date of the ballroom, which is intended to be finished before Trump's term ends in January 2029, signaling the timeline for a major renovation of the White House.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The construction timeline from the start of demolition in October 2025 to completion by January 2029, representing a four-year period of major transformation to the White House East Wing.

keyTakeAways: The White House has begun demolishing part of the East Wing to construct a $250 million ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, the federal agency responsible for overseeing major renovations.

President Donald Trump claims the ballroom will not touch the main White House structure, citing a long-standing desire for a large venue to host dignitaries, and asserts it will be privately funded with no cost to taxpayers.
The ballroom will be 90,000 square feet with a capacity of 999 people, significantly larger than the current East Room which holds about 200 guests.
Construction began on October 20, 2025, with visible demolition of windows and fa√ßade, and site prep work started in September 2025.
Carrier Global Corp. has donated an energy-efficient HVAC system for the ballroom, as confirmed by the company.
The White House has not submitted plans for formal review by the National Capital Planning Commission, raising legal and procedural concerns.
First Lady offices in the East Wing will be temporarily relocated during construction, and the wing will be modernized post-construction.
The project marks the largest structural change to the White House since the addition of the Truman Balcony in 1948.
The White House has not disclosed specific donors to the private funding effort, though Trump claims contributions from 'Patriots, Great American Companies, and, yours truly.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing on October 20, 2025, to construct a $250 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom for President Donald Trump, despite not securing approval from the National Capital Planning Commission. The project, which will accommodate 999 people, was announced in July 2025 and includes temporary relocation of First Lady offices and site preparation work that started in September. Trump claims the ballroom is privately funded by supporters and companies, including Carrier Global Corp., which has donated an energy-efficient HVAC system, and asserts that it will not damage the main White House structure. The construction, scheduled to be completed by January 2029, represents the largest structural change to the Executive Mansion since the Truman Balcony was added in 1948. Legal and procedural concerns persist due to the lack of formal agency review, raising questions about compliance with federal building regulations.
title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom
